faq.headline: Frequently asked questions
faq.a1: Yes, completely free. No API keys, no credit card, no usage limits.
faq.a2: Charts render in your browser. We store chart data so you can access your chart history later. We never store your conversations or personal information.
faq.a3: An MCP App is an interactive extension that renders a visual UI right inside your AI conversation. Unlike regular MCP tools that only return text, MCP Apps can show rich content — like ChartPane's interactive charts. MCP (Model Context Protocol) is the open standard that makes this possible.
faq.q4: Which AI clients does it work with?
faq.a4: Any client that supports MCP Apps: Claude, Claude Desktop, ChatGPT, VS Code, Cursor, Goose, Postman, MCPJam, and more.
faq.q5: Can I create dashboards with multiple charts?
faq.a5: Yes — just ask for a dashboard and get multiple charts in one response. You can request any combination of chart types.
faq.q6: Do I need to know how to code?
faq.a6: No. Describe what you want in plain English and ChartPane handles the rest. If you're already asking Claude to analyze data, you already know how to use ChartPane.

charts_bar.p_what_1: A bar chart uses rectangular bars to represent data values. Each bar's length is proportional to the value it represents. Bars can be oriented vertically or horizontally, and the chart can show a single dataset or multiple datasets grouped or stacked side by side.
charts_bar.p_what_2: Bar charts are the most versatile chart type for comparing discrete categories. They work equally well for small datasets (3-4 items) and larger ones (20+ categories when scrollable). Their familiar form makes them readable by virtually any audience.
charts_bar.when_1: Comparing values across distinct categories (sales by region, scores by student)
charts_bar.when_2: Ranking items from highest to lowest
charts_bar.when_3: Showing change over time when time periods are discrete (quarterly, yearly)
charts_bar.when_4: Comparing multiple series side by side (grouped bar)
charts_bar.when_5: When exact values matter more than trends
charts_bar.best_1: Order bars by value (descending) unless the category order is meaningful
charts_bar.best_2: Start the Y-axis at zero — truncating it exaggerates differences
charts_bar.best_3: Use horizontal bars for long category labels or many categories
charts_bar.best_4: Limit grouped bars to 3-4 series before switching to a different chart type
charts_bar.best_5: Add data labels on or above bars when precise values matter
charts_line.p_what_1: A line chart connects data points with straight lines, showing how a value changes over time or across a sequence. Each point represents a measurement, and the slope of the line between points conveys the rate of change.
charts_line.p_what_2: Line charts are the standard choice for time-series data. Multiple lines on the same chart allow easy comparison of trends across different groups or metrics, making it simple to spot which series is growing faster, converging, or diverging.
charts_line.when_1: Showing trends over time (daily active users, monthly revenue)
charts_line.when_2: Comparing multiple series across the same time period
charts_line.when_3: Highlighting rate of change or acceleration
charts_line.when_4: Continuous data where intermediate values are meaningful
charts_line.when_5: Forecasting or projecting values beyond the current dataset
charts_line.best_1: Use consistent time intervals on the X-axis
charts_line.best_2: Limit to 4-5 lines before the chart becomes cluttered
charts_line.best_3: Label lines directly rather than using a separate legend when possible
charts_line.best_4: Use markers (dots) to emphasize individual data points
charts_line.best_5: Start the Y-axis at zero unless the range of variation is the story
charts_area.p_what_1: An area chart is a line chart with the region below the line filled in. The filled area emphasizes the volume or magnitude of values over time, not just the trend. Stacked area charts show how multiple series add up to a total.
charts_area.p_what_2: Area charts work best when you want to communicate magnitude alongside direction. The visual weight of the filled region makes it immediately clear which values are large versus small. They are especially powerful when comparing a few series that do not overlap much.
charts_area.when_1: Showing volume or magnitude over time (website traffic, energy consumption)
charts_area.when_2: Emphasizing the size of change, not just its direction
charts_area.when_3: Stacked areas to show how parts add up to a total over time
charts_area.when_4: Comparing 2-3 series where overlap is manageable
charts_area.when_5: When the area under the curve has meaningful significance
charts_area.best_1: Use semi-transparent fills so overlapping areas remain visible
charts_area.best_2: Limit to 3-4 series for non-stacked area charts
charts_area.best_3: Prefer stacked area when series sum to a meaningful total
charts_area.best_4: Start the Y-axis at zero — partial fills are misleading otherwise
charts_area.best_5: Add a subtle border along the top of each area to define boundaries
charts_pie.p_what_1: A pie chart divides a circle into slices where each slice's angle is proportional to the value it represents. The whole circle represents 100% of the data, making it ideal for showing how parts contribute to a whole.
charts_pie.p_what_2: Pie charts are most effective when you have a small number of distinct categories and the relative size of each part is the primary message. They are immediately recognizable and require no explanation for most audiences.
charts_pie.when_1: Showing the composition of a whole (market share, budget breakdown)
charts_pie.when_2: When you have 6 or fewer categories
charts_pie.when_3: When relative proportions matter more than absolute values
charts_pie.when_4: Dashboard summaries where a quick part-to-whole view is needed
charts_pie.when_5: When one or two segments are dominant and you want to show that clearly
charts_pie.best_1: Limit to 6 slices; group smaller values into an 'Other' category
charts_pie.best_2: Start the largest slice at 12 o'clock and go clockwise
charts_pie.best_3: Avoid 3D effects — they distort perception of slice sizes
charts_pie.best_4: Add percentage labels directly on each slice
charts_pie.best_5: Do not use a pie chart when values are similar in size — a bar chart reads better
charts_pie.best_6: Use a doughnut chart instead for a more modern look
charts_doughnut.p_what_1: A doughnut chart is a pie chart with a hole in the center. Like a pie chart, each arc represents a proportion of the whole. The center cutout reduces the emphasis on area comparison and creates space for a label, total value, or icon.
charts_doughnut.p_what_2: Doughnut charts have become the preferred alternative to pie charts in modern dashboards. The hollow center looks cleaner, and research suggests people read arc length (the outer ring) more accurately than area (filled pie slices). Multiple doughnut rings can also be nested to compare two related breakdowns.
charts_doughnut.when_1: Same use cases as a pie chart but with a more modern aesthetic
charts_doughnut.when_2: When you want to display a total or summary value in the center
charts_doughnut.when_3: Dashboard KPIs that show progress toward a target (single-value doughnut)
charts_doughnut.when_4: Comparing two related breakdowns using nested rings
charts_doughnut.when_5: When space is limited and you need a compact part-to-whole visualization
charts_doughnut.best_1: Same rules as pie charts: 6 or fewer slices, order by size
charts_doughnut.best_2: Use the center space for a total, percentage, or descriptive label
charts_doughnut.best_3: Keep the cutout ratio consistent across a dashboard (typically 50-70%)
charts_doughnut.best_4: Avoid nesting more than 2 rings; it becomes hard to read
charts_doughnut.best_5: Add percentage labels on or near each arc segment
charts_scatter.p_what_1: A scatter plot (also called an XY chart) places individual data points on a two-dimensional grid where each axis represents a different variable. Each point shows the intersection of two measurements for a single observation. The resulting pattern reveals whether and how the two variables are related.
charts_scatter.p_what_2: Scatter plots are the primary tool for exploring relationships between variables. A tight diagonal cluster suggests strong correlation. A random spread suggests none. Outliers stand out visually, and natural groupings often emerge without any statistical analysis.
charts_scatter.when_1: Exploring correlation between two continuous variables
charts_scatter.when_4: Showing the distribution of data points across two dimensions
charts_scatter.when_5: Comparing groups by plotting each with a different color
charts_scatter.best_1: Use both axes for continuous (numeric) variables, not categories
charts_scatter.best_2: Add axis labels that include units (e.g., 'Hours studied' not just 'X')
charts_scatter.best_3: Use semi-transparent dots when many points overlap
charts_scatter.best_5: Consider adding a trend line if the relationship is meaningful
charts_scatter.best_6: Keep dot sizes consistent unless encoding a third variable (bubble chart)
charts_radar.p_what_1: A radar chart (also called a spider chart or web chart) displays multivariate data on a two-dimensional plot with three or more axes radiating from a center point. Each axis represents a different variable, and data points are plotted along these axes and connected to form a polygon. The shape of the polygon reveals the profile of the data.
charts_radar.p_what_2: Radar charts are uniquely good at showing strengths and weaknesses across multiple dimensions simultaneously. Overlaying two or more polygons makes it easy to compare profiles. A perfectly balanced entity forms a regular polygon, while imbalances create distinctive shapes that are immediately recognizable.
charts_radar.when_1: Comparing profiles across 5-8 dimensions (skill assessments, product features)
charts_radar.when_2: Showing strengths and weaknesses at a glance
charts_radar.when_3: Overlaying 2-3 entities to compare their profiles
charts_radar.best_1: Use 5-8 axes; fewer than 5 is better as a bar chart, more than 8 becomes unreadable
charts_radar.best_2: Ensure all axes use the same scale (e.g., 0-100)
charts_radar.best_3: Limit to 2-3 overlapping polygons for clarity
charts_radar.best_4: Use semi-transparent fills so overlapping areas are visible
charts_radar.best_5: Order axes logically; place related variables adjacent to each other
charts_radar.best_6: Add gridlines so readers can estimate values without hovering
charts_stacked.p_what_1: A stacked chart places multiple data series on top of each other within the same bar or area. Each segment shows one component, and the total height or area represents the sum. This lets you see both the overall total and the individual contributions in a single view.
charts_stacked.p_what_2: Stacking works with both bar charts and area charts. Stacked bar charts are more common for comparing category totals, while stacked area charts are used to show how composition changes over time. A 100% stacked variant normalizes everything to percentages, making it easy to compare proportions even when totals differ.
charts_stacked.when_1: Showing how parts contribute to a total (revenue by channel, budget by department)
charts_stacked.when_2: Comparing totals across categories while seeing the breakdown
charts_stacked.when_3: Tracking how composition changes over time (traffic sources by month)
charts_stacked.when_4: When the total matters as much as individual components
charts_stacked.when_5: Using 100% stacked to compare proportions when absolute values vary widely
charts_stacked.best_1: Limit to 3-5 stacked segments; more becomes hard to read
charts_stacked.best_2: Put the most important or largest segment at the bottom
charts_stacked.best_3: Use consistent colors across time periods for the same category
charts_stacked.best_4: Add data labels or tooltips so exact values are accessible
charts_stacked.best_5: Consider a grouped bar chart instead if comparing individual segment values is more important than totals
charts_stacked.best_6: Use 100% stacked when the story is about proportion, not absolute values

mcp.p_how_they_work_1: Under the hood, an MCP App is an MCP server that registers both tools and a UI resource. When the AI calls a tool, the server returns structured data along with a reference to its UI. The host application (Claude, ChatGPT, VS Code, etc.) loads the UI and passes the data to it. The UI renders client-side — no extra servers, no iframes pointing to third-party domains.
mcp.p_how_they_work_2: This means your data stays local. The UI runs in your client, and the rendering happens in your browser. Nothing is sent to an external service beyond what you already shared with your AI assistant.
mcp.p_where_they_work: MCP Apps work in any client that supports the MCP Apps extension. As of early 2026, that includes:
mcp.p_install_once: You install an MCP App once, and it works across all these clients. No per-client plugins or extensions to manage.
mcp.p_examples_intro: MCP Apps can render anything that makes sense as a visual response:

mcp.li_diagrams: Diagrams — flowcharts, architecture diagrams, entity relationships
mcp.li_forms: Forms and controls — interactive inputs that feed back into the conversation
privacy.p_collect_intro: When you use ChartPane, our server logs minimal request metadata to help us understand usage patterns and improve the service:
privacy.li_collect_type: Chart type requested (e.g., bar, line, pie)
privacy.li_collect_count: Number of datasets and data points
privacy.p_oauth_collect: If OAuth authentication is enabled: your Google profile information (email address and display name) is used to identify your session.
privacy.li_no_data_stored: Chart data values are not stored. The actual numbers, labels, and datasets in your charts are processed in-memory to render the chart and are not persisted to any database.
privacy.li_no_cookies: We do not use cookies for tracking or analytics.
privacy.li_no_analytics: We do not use third-party analytics services.
privacy.li_storage_logs: Request logs are stored in Cloudflare D1 (a serverless SQL database running on Cloudflare's global network).
privacy.li_storage_oauth: OAuth tokens (when authentication is enabled) are stored in Cloudflare Workers KV and scoped to your session.
privacy.p_all_cloudflare: All data is processed and stored on Cloudflare's infrastructure. No data is transferred to other third-party services beyond what is described in this policy.
privacy.li_retention_logs: Request logs are retained for usage analytics. They contain only metadata (chart type, title, dataset count), not your actual data.
privacy.li_retention_oauth: OAuth tokens are scoped to your session and expire when the session ends.
privacy.p_rendering: Charts are rendered entirely client-side in your browser using Chart.js. Your chart data is sent from your AI assistant to ChartPane's server only for validation, then passed directly to the browser for rendering. The data values are not stored on the server.
